repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia-Herzegovina - Mostar Water Supply
            and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bosnia-Herzegovina Mostar Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project had a satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, high institutional development
            impact, and overall satisfactory Bank and Borrower
            performances. Lesson One: Closely project objectives to
            country aspirations during project preparation and to the
            capacity of the government and agency to implement them.
            Lesson Two: Increase the chances of a satisfactory outcome
            and of sustainable benefits by having a sustained
            relationship with a city. The continuous and widespread
            support of the rebuilding of the city of Mostar built trust
            in the Bank as a development partner and fostered acceptance
            of Bank advice and assistance. Lesson Three: Small borrowers
            pay a relatively large cost to comply with the Bank's
            fiduciary requirements for Financial Management Systems
            (FMS). Costs mandated under the Bank's fiduciary FMS
            requirements should be related to the economic capacity of
            the Borrower, the size of the project and the value gained.
            Despite improvements in the Bank's FMS requirements
            since project preparation, they continue to be both costly
            and unrelated to client value. Lesson Four: The Project
            showed the virtues of limiting the externally contracted
            consultancy to that which the Mostar Water and Sewerage
            Utility was not able to create with its own staff. The
            decision to create financial and technical project
            implementation capacity within the utility itself, with its
            own staff that stayed on past the project's end, was
            vindicated by economy and institution building. Lesson Five:
            The Project demonstrates that a public sector operator can
            improve service quality and operational efficiency without
            the help of private sector operators.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Mostar Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Mostar Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project aims to create a unified water supply and sanitation
            utility for the city of Mostar, and to improve service. The
            project consists of six components. 1) The priority
            investments for water supply rehabilitation and improvement
            component will finance installation of new water supply
            equipment, replacement of pipes with leaks, construction of
            pump stations, rehabilitation of existing resources, and
            purchase of computers and related equipment in support of
            the project implementation. 2) The Water Distribution
            Network Rehabilitation and Improvement Fund will support the
            improvement for the distribution system. 3) The sewerage
            network rehabilitation component will finance urgent
            rehabilitation and repair of selected sewers and sewer
            maintenance equipment and pipe replacement. 4) The
            Institutional Strengthening Fund will support the Mostar
            Water Supply and Sewerage Utility in terms of institutional
            strengthening and capacity building as well as training for
            staff. 5) The technical advisor/engineering services
            component will support activities to assist both project
            implementation and provide technical assistance for
            institutional improvement. 6) The operating expenditures
            component will support critical expenditures for a two-year
            period immediately following the merger of the two water
            companies - the Eastern Utility and the Western Utility.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Mostar Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the framework for preparation of
            the Mostar Water Supply, and Sanitation Project, the
            environmental assessment explores potential adverse effects
            on the environment. Although sewage collection systems are
            in place, waste water treatment is rare, and, industrial,
            and waste water effluents discharge - untreated - into the
            area's rivers. Furthermore, Mostar's surrounding
            areas, have no sewers, but latrines, rarely with any septic
            tanks. This poses serious bio-diversity threats, due to the
            potential effluent toxicity, and on the population's
            health, since the risks of insufficient quantity, and/or
            quality of drinking water, are high. Measures to mitigate
            adversity suggest, primarily, that adequate institutional
            arrangements enforce monitoring of microbiological, and
            physico-chemical testing, to control health, and sanitary
            risks. Inspection of industrial, and domestic effluent
            controls should be conducted to prevent ecological
            degradation. During construction, it is recommended to
            phase-out water supply systems, and, although solid waste
            management is not part of this report - in light of the high
            costs of waste water treatment plants -, the use of adequate
            septic tanks is recommended.
